segments.text: All right, guys. I travel a lot. I'm a
big traveler. This job, it really
requires it. There are a ton of these
product conferences to go to. I've got
friends and family in Australia. I used
to live in New York. And hopefully this
year, I can actually go on a vacation.
Anyway, since I just got back from a
trip, I thought, what better time to
just share my backpack and all the tech
that I carry around with me. Now, of
course, links to everything that I do
talk about today will be below the
video. And guys, I really live out of
this backpack. For anyone who knows me
personally, you'll know that I'm rarely
without it, no matter where I am in the
world. You know, I just enjoy going to a
cool coffee store, setting up there, and
just getting some work done. Yes, I
really do enjoy working on this job, and
I don't mind doing it in my free time so
long as I'm in a cool environment. And
to do that, I need the backpack. So,
with that said, what is it? It's a TUMI,
specifically the Alpha Bravo Kingsville
Deluxe. It is without a doubt the best
purchase I've ever made. Seriously, I
got mine in 2016 and it still looks
great and has no major issues. That's 9
years. And I brought this thing to
Germany. It's been to India, to
Colombia, Canada, Mexico. You guys get
the point. It really is built like a
tank. Seriously, every zipper still
works perfectly. And to my eyes, it
still looks stylish and pretty high-end.
And on that note, owning something
luxurious like this, it does make me
feel a little proud carrying it around
with me. Now, of course, it's not just
how the backpack looks, it's also how
functional it is. You see, most
backpacks I've tried, they just topple
over when they have stuff in them. This
one stays upright. It's really quite
sturdy. It's also got a wide variety of
pockets, which makes it just easy to
find what I need. And on those pockets,
one cool thing about this backpack is
that if you leave the zippers open,
things they don't really fall out. It's
kind of how the pockets are shaped. You
see, they all curve in. And since the
material is a little rigid, even if the
zipper is open, the pocket stays
somewhat closed. Now, unfortunately, my
specific backpack, it just isn't
available anymore, but it's a 29 L one.
So, here's two that I found that are
super close. You got the Alpha Bravo
Search. That's a little smaller, and
then there's the Alpha Bravo Nomatic,
which is a little larger. I'll link both
of them down below. Highly recommend it.
All right, next up is my jacket. It's a
Canada Goose Cabri Hooded jacket. I
think that's how I pronounce it. It's a
similar situation to the Tumi backpack.
My strategy with these material
purchases that I own is to own as little
as possible, but for the few things that
I do buy to spend a good amount of money
to get something nice that I just keep
for ages and I feel great wearing it.
Now, obviously, really, obviously, you
don't need to spend big on a Canadian
goose jacket, but I will vouch for its
quality. Once again, my one has really
lasted the test of time. It still just
looks like I bought it yesterday, even
though I bought it years ago. And as a
luxury item, as I said, I feel kind of
special wearing it. And of course, guys,
it is functional. It's very warm, yet
it's super light and just packs down so
tiny that I can easily fit it in my
backpack. I take it with me everywhere I
go, even in Arizona. Guys, there's
nothing worse than being cold. And
sometimes even here, it's like boiling
hot outside, but inside they're just
pumping the air conditioning. It's also
just a great jacket to wear on the plane
as it's warm, but not too bulky. All
right, laptop time. I currently use two.
the MacBook Pro 14 and the Razer Blade
16. Now, I carry at least one of them
with me at all times. Guess what? A lot
of the times I actually carry both. They
both do fit in my backpack. The MacBook
Pro 14, I've picked it because it's just
reliable. Everything about it works good
to great. I don't have to worry about
things like it battery running out and
it's powerful enough to edit my videos
on. By the way, the config I have is the
M4 Pro 14 core version with 24 gig of
memory and 1 TB of storage. That's my
favorite config right now. It's good
enough for pretty much 99% of what
people are going to do on it. Also, it's
14.2 in display. It may not seem like
such a large one, but because it's
incredibly pixel dense, 254 pixels per
inch, you can just see more content on
it. Everything looks so sharp that you
can just zoom out. Its display is also
very bright, so I don't have to worry
about reflections, and it does have an
SD card reader, which means one less
thing to carry around. Now, sometimes I
don't bring the MacBook Pro. Instead, I
bring the Razer Blade 16. It's a premium
feeling 16-inch gaming laptop that is
very slim and light, yet it's still very
powerful, at least for gaming. The 2025
model, they actually changed the
keyboard, and it's now super comfortable
to type on. I really like it. There are
two main times that I bring the Blade
with me, not the MacBook. The first is
when I'm going locally to a coffee
store, and I just want to work off a
larger screen. The second is when I'm
going somewhere where I like to game. I
recently visited a friend in Chicago and
I knew I'd be doing a lot of gaming, so
obviously I brought the Blade. Now, on
the flip side, the reason I don't only
use the Blade is it's just unreliable,
particularly its battery life. All
blades I've tried, they have
horrendously bad battery life. Most last
around 2 to 3 hours, at least for my
real world use case. So, if I'm not
certain I'm going to find an outlet
where I'm going, I just can't bring the
Blade. I have to bring the MacBook Pro.
In fact, at the conference I was just
at, I heard a loud crack when I was
using the Blade 16. That is, and it just
turned off black screen. Guys, as I
said, it's really unreliable. You have
to be very patient if you're going to
get a Blade. And to be honest, if I
hadn't bought one for our reviews, I
probably would have bought the Legion 7i
if it was my money. It is physically
larger, but it's more reliable. I'll
link both down below. Most people, I
think, should probably buy the Legion.
Plus the Legion. It looks much nicer
with my mouse as it's white. I use the
Logitech G75 and I'm obsessed by it. A
lot of gaming mice, you see, they're
either too large for my hands or too
small. This one is perfect. It's
wireless and can be used with either
Bluetooth or Logitech's proprietary
light speed that uses the included USB
receiver. The G705, it lasts forever on
battery and it's incredibly lightweight.
I absolutely love it and I have it
permanently in my backpack. That being
said, I don't use it with my MacBook
Pro. I find the MacBook's trackpads,
they're just good enough that you don't
need it. For chargers, I use the UG Nexo
100 W charger. It's small and compact
enough, and it has plenty of charging
ports. It also ticks a lot of boxes.
It's a 20 volt charger, which is what
gaming laptops require, like this one.
It has the usual array of fast charging
options, and it doesn't fall out of the
wall. I used to use their Nexo Pro 100 W
charger, but it just wasn't well
balanced. It would fall out of the wall
if the outlet wasn't tight enough. This
is an issue on planes, by the way. Their
outlets, they're just not tight. Just a
heads up, UG Green have sponsored this
channel in the past. That's why we have
so much UG Green stuff here. This video,
though, it isn't sponsored. We just like
their stuff. Now, if you do want me to
do a comparison of the best USB
chargers, leave a comment down below.
I'm actually interested to see like, is
it worth paying the extra money for
something like a UG Green versus a very
generic one? For cables, I travel with
one long and one short. It's nice having
two different lengths. Obviously, I can
adapt. Plus, when I'm in a hotel, I can
charge two things at the same time.
Again, super obvious. These are braided
UG green charging cables. Braided. They
just work best as they don't get twisted
and stuck. Other than these two cables,
the only additional one I bring with me
is my charging cable for my Garmin
watch. Now, on that note, although I
don't technically have it in my
backpack, a lot of you guys just ask me
what watch I use. It's the Gin Fenix 7.
I believe it's the 7S. I've been using
Fenix watches for a long time. I
absolutely swear by them. Guys, an Apple
Watch, it lasts one day on battery. This
Phoenix lasts 11. That is a huge
difference. I don't want another thing
that I have to constantly charge. The
reason the Phoenix lasts so long is
they've essentially just stripped out
all the stuff that most people don't use
on the eyewatch, but they've left the
stuff that people do use, especially
fitness enthusiasts like me. When I'm
doing CrossFit, I use it to keep track
of my heart rate so I don't die. When
I'm doing lap swimming, I use it to
count my laps. It is so boring swimming
laps by yourself. It's just really easy
for your mind to wander and just forget
to count. The Phoenix, it makes lap
swimming better. It just makes me focus
on my next goal. And of course, it keeps
me on track. It also tracks my steps, my
car race. I can see the weather on it.
As I said, everything I need without the
stress of having to constantly charge
it. And guess what? It also tells the
time. Now, in the front pocket of my
backpack, I keep my earphones. I use the
Power Beats Pro 2. I've been a Power
Beats Pro user for years. I've tried
many others, like, you know, Apple's
AirPod Pros, Samsung Galaxy Buds, but I
just keep coming back to the Power Beats
Pros. The main reason is that they wrap
around my ear. I do a lot of fitness as
I said and other earbuds they just fall
out particularly when I'm lifting
weights. The update to the Power Beats
Pro 2 from version one, it was huge.
These now have much longer battery life.
Seriously, they easily get me through an
entire day. They now have active noise
cancelling, which obviously very helpful
when I'm on a plane. And the case, it is
smaller. Don't get me wrong, still a
large case, but it's not obnoxiously
large as it was before. For my water
bottle, I use a Yeti 26 oz. It just fits
perfectly in the side of my backpack and
it keeps my water nice and cold. I am a
sucker for ice cold water. All right,
next up I'm going to talk about cameras.
I go to a lot of conferences as I've
said and sometimes I'm traveling for a
really long time and I just want an
option to make a video for you guys if
something comes up. Now, for these kind
of trips, I bring my Sony a6700 with me.
It's a great camera. It's a high-end
APS-C, which means it has a smaller
sensor than full-frame cameras. But this
has the benefit of being more compact
and portable, especially the lenses.
Now, on the flip side, it's also a
noticeable step up from a phone's
camera. I pair it with a Sigma 18 to
50mm f/2.8 zoom, which I must admit I
don't love. Sony has a 16 to 55mm f/2.8
zoom lens, which I really like a lot
more. We have several of them in the
studio. I'm looking at one right now.
Now, the extra reach of the 50 mm to 55
doesn't sound like a lot, but it does
make a difference, especially at events
where you just may be far away and you
want to punch in. Same goes at the other
end, 16 to 18 mil, 16, just wider. Plus,
the zoom on the Sony lens, it turns the
same direction as all our other Sony
lenses. The Sigma zoom ring, it turns
the opposite way. Now, the reason I've
stuck with the Sigma lens is its size
and weight. It's just so much lighter
than those Sony lenses. That being said,
I am tempted to switch back to the Sony.
Guys, if you don't enjoy the gear you're
using, you just don't use it. Now, I
pair the Sony with a Manfrotto carbon
fiber tripod. It's [clears throat]
somewhat light and it does somewhat pack
down small, but it does have an amazing
pan and tilt head. Bringing it with me
means I can shoot most things very well.
I can film talking head videos if I want
to interview someone. I can film wide
shots to set the scene. and I can film
tight shots just to punch in on certain
product details. Now, even though I've
tried to optimize my Sony setup for
weight as much as I can, it's still
somewhat cumbersome, especially that
tripod. So, this year I've added a DJI
Pocket Osmo 3. And guys, it has been
amazing. Its camera is mounted on a
gimbal, so you can do these really cool
smooth pan shots. It handles different
lighting situations surprisingly well.
It can easily switch between portrait or
landscape modes. And unlike a phone's
camera, it can turn its lens around, so
I can always see how I'm framed in its
little monitor. Now, you can get a
wireless mic for it that connects
automatically, which is again very
useful. I use that mic all the time just
to take notes on and to interview
people. The DJI's main downside, though,
is that it has a single wide lens, but
rumor has it a version 4 is coming out
with two lenses, the wide one and
hopefully a tighter one. Now, if that
happens, I will definitely upgrade. It
would hopefully mean I wouldn't have to
bring the Sony quite as often. With that
said, I have a lot more videos to make.
I really do. So, I'm off. As I said,
links down below to everything I
mentioned today. And as I always say, if
you are in the market to buy a laptop,
make sure to check out our website,
bestlaptop.deals.
Over there, we are demystifying laptop
shopping. Clear recommendations for each
type of laptop buyer. You can even
combine use cases together to get a
custom recommendation. We also track
prices right across retailers so you
know where to go to get the best deal
and of course what is the best time to
buy because that makes a big difference.
Till [snorts] next time, go do something
awesome with your day and I will catch
you later.
